prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the general collection and purchased from Second Life Books.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection original processed by Betsy Pittman in June 1990. Finding aid revised by Susan King in June 2002. Accession numbers: 90-Jun-79; 90-Dec-167; 91-Jul-24; 95-Oct-39

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The first women's rights meeting in the United States was a social gathering of five women in Seneca Falls, New York in 1848. The women who attended the meeting, Lucretia Mott, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Mary Ann McClintock, Martha Wright, and Jane Hunt organized a convention at Seneca Falls later the same year that included approximately 300 men and women and set the movement for women's suffrage in full motion. After seven decades of lobbying and outreach by several generations of activists, the 19th Amendment to the Constitution giving women the right to vote was ratified in 1920.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Fifteen printed items were purchased from book dealers in the 1990's. Most of these printed handbills and pamphlets are from the state of New York circa 1917 and before. There are examples of both pro and anti suffrage materials in the collection.
Published in New York by Andrews
Published in New York by the National Woman Suffrage Association

unittitle.title: Dark and Dangerous Side of Woman Suffrage,

scopecontent.p: Published in New York by the Women Voters' Anti-Suffrage Party

unittitle.title: Don't Forget to Vote for Woman Suffrage,

scopecontent.p: Published in New York by the New York State Woman Suffrage Party

unittitle.title: Extracts from Addresses of the Rt. Rev. Wm. Croswell Doane, June 6, 1894 and June 6, 1895

scopecontent.p: Published in New York by the Albany Anti-Suffrage Association

unittitle.title: Few Words in Behalf of the Loyal Women of the United States,

scopecontent.p: Published in New York by the Loyal Publication Society

unittitle.title: How to Vote for Woman Suffrage Amendment, Election Day, November 6th, 1917

scopecontent.p: Published in New York by the New York State Woman Suffrage Party

unittitle.title: Protest Against the Granting of Municipal Suffrage to Women, Chicago,

scopecontent.p: Published in Chicago by the Association Opposed to the Extension of Suffrage to Women
Published by Cargill Company for the National American Woman Suffrage Association

unittitle.title: Votes for Women! The Woman's Reason,

scopecontent.p: Published in New York by the New York State Woman Suffrage Association

unittitle.title: Why New York Men Should Give New York Women the Vote,

scopecontent.p: Published in New York by the Empire State Campaign Committee

unittitle.title: Why Working Women Want the Vote, Mass Meeting...to Celebrate Passage of Suffrage Amendment by Legislature,

scopecontent.p: Published in New York by the New York State Woman Suffrage Association

unittitle.title: Woman Suffrage Above Human Law. Letter from Gerrit Smith to Susan B. Anthony,

scopecontent.p: Published in New York by the New York State Woman Suffrage Party
